review_title: Honeywell Clearwater  management is very toxic
job_title: ISC Engineering Support in Clearwater, FL
pros: Very little pros while working for Honeywell for over 20 years. Ever since Allied Signal's take over, merit increases were non existent and every benefit was widdled down year after year.  Their unlimited vacation policy is the true example of bait and switch. Every year cooperate will come up with new and improved ideas to reduce employees benefits in one way or another.
cons: Former employee of over 20 years, their management at all levels is very toxic. A lot, not all are non degreed managers that made it to their level purely by the buddy system. If you are not in that system and bow down to management, your career will go no where. They do not encourage or attempt to retain good talent. As many companies are doing now their are hiring a lot of new graduates, my advice to them is use Honeywell as a stepping stone, work a year or two and move on. Non degreed managers and non technical managers run rampant. Managers are not there to help their employees but to force employees to adhere to Honeywell 's policies. Very few capable managers that were technical over the years would actually contribute and help.

Terrible atmosphere, controlling and vindictive management. They treat the Union employees like the enemy (very much "us" versus "them" mentality). They have taken away virtually every benefit that existed when I started working there and say it's because they don't have money. Google the company you will quickly see the billions of dollars they've profited during the pandemic, and somehow still tried to justify lay-offs. By working here, you are signing up to be treated like cattle. They do not care about you or your well being at all, they just want a warm body to show up every day. It's so sad because the site has so much potential to be a great place to work, but the life and morale has been completely zapped. I have seen many brilliant people come and go.
There is opportunity to move up the ladder but don't expect a pay increase to take on additional work :)

review_title: Honeywell is not what you think
pros: Good exposure and learning experience.
cons:
High (internal) turnover, management and employees creates disruption and work imbalance. It affects employee performance evaluation, follow up and succession plans. For business convenience lateral movements are promoted without employee agreement.
Changing positions is a must for salary increase. 
Employees deciding to stay in same group are not rewarded or promoted. Salary increases are forfeited for company convenience (or no salary increase) and not credited later. To improve salary is a must to move and work jobs outside Honeywell and then return.
Work balance is a dream not a reality. Work load is not balanced among groups (this is the result of frequent internal movements at managerial and below levels)

pros: Strong leadership to drive company's transformation from heavies to software. OK salaries, and bonuses at all levels.
cons: After a while, this company looks more like a crabs basket. Hard to admit, mostly from the inside but the reality is that the company culture is extremely toxic, not only for individuals but for customers and partners too. As an example, this is the kind of company which constantly promotes Work-Life balance principles while everybody is simply driven to give it all to work. Diversity? I've rather just seen communities gathered by locations than diversified workforces across functions, and the unit's leaders all seem to look alike and share same values. A lot of BS, and an auto-assumed aggressiveness, as in the Top Corporate Principle "Be a Zealot for Growth", commonly interpreted from the bottom to the top as act borderline with integrity. From the outside, and in a new role I now know there are successful growing organizations which do apply "employee consideration" principles for real.

review_title: Not the Environment Most Will Enjoy
job_title: Director, Global Marketing in Richardson, TX
pros: Honeywell has very flexible hours, work rules and vacation policies. Their onboarding was top notch and they leave a very good first impression.
cons:
I joined the office in Richardson with 30+ years experience in large aerospace operations. The physical environment was the worst I have ever encountered. Restrooms without hot water, decrepit furniture and asbestos warning stickers on every wall. 

The work environment was slightly worse. Systems across sites and programs have never been integrated leaving gaps in all manner of data. Turnover at our site exceeded 40% and executive tenure was measured in days or weeks. My team had 2 Presidents and 5 General Managers in 14 months.

The culture in Richardson was really more tribal than corporate. Small groups banded together and did their best, largely without resources. My organization never had a marketing budget, travel budget, research budget or even the ability to host a customer symposium, but we were expected to intimately understand our customer’s future plans and drive product sales. The disconnect between desired outcomes and available resources was so acute, staff was left wondering if abject failure was some secret goal for the group. 

To make sure moral never rose above that of an island prison, Honeywell routinely furloughs 50% of the staff to reduce expenses and “make” a quarterly number. Apparently, this is a long-term practice, that oddly, never gets disclosed in interviews. 

This environment only seemed tenable to employees who had never worked outside Honeywell, who needed Honeywell to support H-1B visas or who genuinely thought, “this is terrible, but I have 30 years of my life to spend fixing it.” If you don’t fit those categories, run away.

review_title: A decent place to work with a lot of room for improvement.
job_title: Principal Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
- Unlimited Vacation & 4 Weeks of Paternity Leave for Fathers
- Flexible Work Schedule (ability to work from home when needed)
- Ability to Travel (Globally)
- Decent pay & Opportunity for Bonuses
cons:
- Unlimited Vacation is based on workload and most staff are too busy to get approval for more than a few consecutive days off at a time.
- Lack of Training for new employees and almost non-existent training for established employees.
- Inability to "absorb" market fluctuations and employees with less than 2 years of experience are cut quickly and replaced by contractors.
- Dental & Vision insurance was cut, but "pre-negotiated" programs can be utilized.
- Health Penalties (Financial Deductions) for Smokers, High BMI, High BP, but there are no incentives to be healthy.
- Most managers are just "yes-people" to the managers above them. 
- Stock holders are held to a high regard than employees.
- Quality in projects has disappeared as financial obligations are the driving force for everything.

job_title: Advanced Cyber Sec Archt/Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Large company so you have lots of opportunity to move to different roles. I have seen benefits erode over 15+ years, but from others I have spoken with they are still better than most companies now a days. My experience with direct management has been excellent. However, the company is so large it probably varies depending on who that manager is. HR has always been great. There are many good people here.
cons:
If you are not a job/role hopper your salary will stagnate. It seems the only way to increase your wages is to move roles as often as you can. 
Over 15+ years I have seen a huge change in culture from a family focused company to just being a number. Unfortunately, this is probably how most corporations are now, but sad to witness it happen here. 
There seems to never been enough people to get done what is required to be done. You could literally work around the clock and still be behind. They have taken the lets reduce staff until stuff starts breaking approach.

job_title: Inside Sales Associate in Basildon, England
pros:
- The name looks good on your Resume/CV
- IT is quick to respond
- They got me on Payroll on time & paid every time
cons:
- Very poor culture

- This is 100% an Account Manager Role, not Inside Sales. You are upselling to existing accounts.

- You are held to the same standard as the Territory Account Managers but with many, MANY more accounts that spend nowhere near as much as a TAMs account does. 

- Poor communication from Management.

- Training is a joke - They give you the material and expect you to understand internal procedures on your own. The training that was provided was done by people that clearly did not want to be involved in training new employees. (Except for the Technical Team, he actually seemed like he was enjoying passing on his industry knowledge)

- They make you do a bunch of sensitivity training but on a day to day basis it all goes out the window.

- You are paid on the 15th of the month

- It took them 3 months to give me a decision after my interviews. I was the one chasing them for the information - In hindsight I 100% should have taken that as foreshadowing for what was to come. 

- Upon leaving they tell you that they will mail you your final pay cheque as a paper cheque, but they can not give you a date as to when it will arrive...

review_title: Honeywell Clearwater  management is very toxic
job_title: ISC Engineering Support in Clearwater, FL
pros: Very little pros while working for Honeywell for over 20 years. Ever since Allied Signal's take over, merit increases were non existent and every benefit was widdled down year after year.  Their unlimited vacation policy is the true example of bait and switch. Every year cooperate will come up with new and improved ideas to reduce employees benefits in one way or another.
cons: Former employee of over 20 years, their management at all levels is very toxic. A lot, not all are non degreed managers that made it to their level purely by the buddy system. If you are not in that system and bow down to management, your career will go no where. They do not encourage or attempt to retain good talent. As many companies are doing now their are hiring a lot of new graduates, my advice to them is use Honeywell as a stepping stone, work a year or two and move on. Non degreed managers and non technical managers run rampant. Managers are not there to help their employees but to force employees to adhere to Honeywell 's policies. Very few capable managers that were technical over the years would actually contribute and help.

review_title: Good pay and that's about it
pros: Our hourly compensation was very high, HOWEVER, that is solely due to our union negotiations with the company. I cannot think of any other single "pro" to working for them.
cons:
Terrible atmosphere, controlling and vindictive management. They treat the Union employees like the enemy (very much "us" versus "them" mentality). They have taken away virtually every benefit that existed when I started working there and say it's because they don't have money. Google the company you will quickly see the billions of dollars they've profited during the pandemic, and somehow still tried to justify lay-offs. By working here, you are signing up to be treated like cattle. They do not care about you or your well being at all, they just want a warm body to show up every day. It's so sad because the site has so much potential to be a great place to work, but the life and morale has been completely zapped. I have seen many brilliant people come and go.
There is opportunity to move up the ladder but don't expect a pay increase to take on additional work :)

review_title: Honeywell is not what you think
pros: Good exposure and learning experience.
cons:
High (internal) turnover, management and employees creates disruption and work imbalance. It affects employee performance evaluation, follow up and succession plans. For business convenience lateral movements are promoted without employee agreement.
Changing positions is a must for salary increase. 
Employees deciding to stay in same group are not rewarded or promoted. Salary increases are forfeited for company convenience (or no salary increase) and not credited later. To improve salary is a must to move and work jobs outside Honeywell and then return.
Work balance is a dream not a reality. Work load is not balanced among groups (this is the result of frequent internal movements at managerial and below levels)

pros: Strong leadership to drive company's transformation from heavies to software. OK salaries, and bonuses at all levels.
cons: After a while, this company looks more like a crabs basket. Hard to admit, mostly from the inside but the reality is that the company culture is extremely toxic, not only for individuals but for customers and partners too. As an example, this is the kind of company which constantly promotes Work-Life balance principles while everybody is simply driven to give it all to work. Diversity? I've rather just seen communities gathered by locations than diversified workforces across functions, and the unit's leaders all seem to look alike and share same values. A lot of BS, and an auto-assumed aggressiveness, as in the Top Corporate Principle "Be a Zealot for Growth", commonly interpreted from the bottom to the top as act borderline with integrity. From the outside, and in a new role I now know there are successful growing organizations which do apply "employee consideration" principles for real.

review_title: Not the Environment Most Will Enjoy
job_title: Director, Global Marketing in Richardson, TX
pros: Honeywell has very flexible hours, work rules and vacation policies. Their onboarding was top notch and they leave a very good first impression.
cons:
I joined the office in Richardson with 30+ years experience in large aerospace operations. The physical environment was the worst I have ever encountered. Restrooms without hot water, decrepit furniture and asbestos warning stickers on every wall. 

The work environment was slightly worse. Systems across sites and programs have never been integrated leaving gaps in all manner of data. Turnover at our site exceeded 40% and executive tenure was measured in days or weeks. My team had 2 Presidents and 5 General Managers in 14 months.

The culture in Richardson was really more tribal than corporate. Small groups banded together and did their best, largely without resources. My organization never had a marketing budget, travel budget, research budget or even the ability to host a customer symposium, but we were expected to intimately understand our customer’s future plans and drive product sales. The disconnect between desired outcomes and available resources was so acute, staff was left wondering if abject failure was some secret goal for the group. 

To make sure moral never rose above that of an island prison, Honeywell routinely furloughs 50% of the staff to reduce expenses and “make” a quarterly number. Apparently, this is a long-term practice, that oddly, never gets disclosed in interviews. 

This environment only seemed tenable to employees who had never worked outside Honeywell, who needed Honeywell to support H-1B visas or who genuinely thought, “this is terrible, but I have 30 years of my life to spend fixing it.” If you don’t fit those categories, run away.

review_title: A decent place to work with a lot of room for improvement.
job_title: Principal Engineer in Des Plaines, IL
pros:
- Unlimited Vacation & 4 Weeks of Paternity Leave for Fathers
- Flexible Work Schedule (ability to work from home when needed)
- Ability to Travel (Globally)
- Decent pay & Opportunity for Bonuses
cons:
- Unlimited Vacation is based on workload and most staff are too busy to get approval for more than a few consecutive days off at a time.
- Lack of Training for new employees and almost non-existent training for established employees.
- Inability to "absorb" market fluctuations and employees with less than 2 years of experience are cut quickly and replaced by contractors.
- Dental & Vision insurance was cut, but "pre-negotiated" programs can be utilized.
- Health Penalties (Financial Deductions) for Smokers, High BMI, High BP, but there are no incentives to be healthy.
- Most managers are just "yes-people" to the managers above them. 
- Stock holders are held to a high regard than employees.
- Quality in projects has disappeared as financial obligations are the driving force for everything.

pros: Large company so you have lots of opportunity to move to different roles. I have seen benefits erode over 15+ years, but from others I have spoken with they are still better than most companies now a days. My experience with direct management has been excellent. However, the company is so large it probably varies depending on who that manager is. HR has always been great. There are many good people here.
cons:
If you are not a job/role hopper your salary will stagnate. It seems the only way to increase your wages is to move roles as often as you can. 
Over 15+ years I have seen a huge change in culture from a family focused company to just being a number. Unfortunately, this is probably how most corporations are now, but sad to witness it happen here. 
There seems to never been enough people to get done what is required to be done. You could literally work around the clock and still be behind. They have taken the lets reduce staff until stuff starts breaking approach.

review_title: Very poor experience - Left after 6 months
job_title: Inside Sales Associate in Basildon, East of England, England
pros:
- The name looks good on your Resume/CV
- IT is quick to respond
- They got me on Payroll on time & paid every time
cons:
- Very poor culture

- This is 100% an Account Manager Role, not Inside Sales. You are upselling to existing accounts.

- You are held to the same standard as the Territory Account Managers but with many, MANY more accounts that spend nowhere near as much as a TAMs account does. 

- Poor communication from Management.

- Training is a joke - They give you the material and expect you to understand internal procedures on your own. The training that was provided was done by people that clearly did not want to be involved in training new employees. (Except for the Technical Team, he actually seemed like he was enjoying passing on his industry knowledge)

- They make you do a bunch of sensitivity training but on a day to day basis it all goes out the window.

- You are paid on the 15th of the month

- It took them 3 months to give me a decision after my interviews. I was the one chasing them for the information - In hindsight I 100% should have taken that as foreshadowing for what was to come. 

- Upon leaving they tell you that they will mail you your final pay cheque as a paper cheque, but they can not give you a date as to when it will arrive...

pros: Offer every other Friday off in theory, but so busy rarely get it off on a regular basis.  A lot of remote opportunities currently.

review_title: No work-life balance. Hire and Fire culture with moderately low salaries.
pros: Focused on innovation. If you are from core engineering background then have a lot of scope and guidance available from really talented people to file patents.
cons:
Though the company is product-based, it hardly follows the culture of product-based companies. There is no work-life balance, managers usually give a lot of work on Thursday and Friday nights and they don't bother calling you for work on weekends. 
The attitude of management is like they own you. Salary and hikes are also not very impressive, if you are in the good book of managers, you will get a good hike. Hardly any onsite opportunity. I saw a few very talented people wasting time here.
